Award.AwardTitle: 3rd Annual Symposium and Bootcamp on the Science of Security (HotSoS2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Science of Security" (SoS) encompasses research in cybersecurity that emphasizes the means by which researchers and adopters can gain confidence in research results. The SoS approach emphasizes both the activity of scientific knowledge discovery and also the improvements of scientific methods for validating predictions though logic or through potentially repeatable empirical observational and experimental analyses. It also emphasizes gaining of coherency in the scientific activity. Science of Security emphasizes the methodology of research in cyber-security as much as the results of that research.

This grant provides funding for students to participate in the 2016 Annual Symposium and Bootcamp on the Science of Security (HotSoS), held in April 2016 at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh PA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background. The Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) Science of Security (SoS) Lablet advances basic scientific research in support of the cybersecurity mission of the National Security Agency. The Science of Security community centers its research on results and methods associated with an identified set of five "hard problems." The CMU SoS Lablet focuses primarily on two of these problems: (1) scale through composability of modeling and reasoning and on human behavior and (5) usability for developers, evaluators, operators, and end users. The CMU Lablet also addresses the other three SoS hard problems, which relate to resiliency, metrics, and collaboration policy.

Particiption. The CMU SoS Lablet includes a set of interlinked technical projects that involve fifteen faculty from more than four CMU academic departments. It also includes as subcontractors seven partner universities: Cornell University, University of California at Irvine and Berkeley, University of Pittsburgh, Wayne State University, University of Nebraska, and University of Texas, San Antonio. More than ten PhD students are supported, as well as several postdoctoral researchers. All the work is fundamental research with open publication.

This project. The intention of this NSF project is to increase participation by graduate students in the annual symposium on the Science of Security, HotSoS 2016, which was hosted by Carnegie Mellon in April 2016. The PI of this project served as General Chair for the two-day HotSoS symposium. The symposium featured invited speakers, refereed papers, poster sessions, and panel discussions. There were approximately 100 attendees. 

Results. This grant enabled four graduate students from other universities to attend and participate in the HotSoS 2016 meeting.
